G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Quincy, which lies within Norfolk County.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of Quincy Bistro, owed Plaintiff—as a lawful business invitee—a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining its premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of any dangers of which it knew or reasonably should have known.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The excerpt provided is only a short concurrence by Justice Kaplan criticizing the continued use of trespasser classifications. It does not discuss, much less articulate, the specific duty owed by a business owner to a lawful business invitee regarding maintaining safe premises or warning of known dangers. While the full Mounsey decision does address occupiers’ duties generally, this specific text cannot be said to support the proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner must act as a reasonable person in the maintenance of property in view of the probability of injury to others.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the Massachusetts duty standard for a property owner, citing Mounsey v. Ellard, as a duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition in view of circumstances including the likelihood of injury. It then frames the negligence question as whether an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken additional steps to prevent the accident. This directly supports the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, a property owner must act as a reasonable person in maintenance of property considering the probability of injury to others.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, supra, quoting Smith v. Arbaugh’s Restaurant, Inc., 469 F.2d 97, 100 (D.C. Cir. 1972), cert. denied, 412 U.S. 939 (1973). … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps…to prevent the accident that occurred.”

Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (l.raw_text: Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (liability where owner knew or should have known of foreign substance on floor)
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (l.proposition: Defendant’s employees had actual or constructive notice of the hazardous condition.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (l.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (l.support_reasoning: The case discusses when a defendant can be found negligent based on actual or constructive notice of a foreign substance, but it ultimately holds that the evidence was insufficient to show the defendant had such notice. The court reverses the jury verdict and orders judgment for the defendant, explicitly concluding that the circumstantial evidence did not establish that the substance was present long enough for the defendant’s employees to have actual or constructive knowledge. Thus, it does not support the proposition that the defendant’s employees had actual or constructive notice of the hazardous condition; it stands for the opposite result on these facts.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (l.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required… The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element… Exceptions sustained. Judgment for the defendant.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: The foreseeability of harm under these circumstances is clear, as slip-and-fall injuries from wet floors are a common and well-understood danger.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does not explicitly say that wet or icy slip-and-fall risks are ‘common and well‑understood,’ but its entire analysis assumes such harm is foreseeable and treats slip‑and‑falls on snow and ice as a standard, recognizable premises liability hazard. In abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, the court emphasizes the general duty to protect lawful visitors from known or reasonably knowable dangers like snow and ice on walkways and parking lots, which aligns with the notion that such harms are foreseeably associated with wet/icy surfaces.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.… Under this traditional premises liability standard, a fact finder will determine what snow and ice removal efforts are reasonable in light of the expense they impose on the landowner and the probability and seriousness of the foreseeable harm to others.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the dangerous condition or to warn of it constituted unreasonable conduct falling below the standard of care required of proprietors.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts the mode-of-operation approach, under which a proprietor may be liable where it could reasonably foresee a dangerous condition and "failed to take adequate steps to forestall resulting injuries." That is a direct articulation that failing to remedy or warn of such conditions can constitute unreasonable conduct below the required standard of care. However, the Court ultimately remands rather than definitively holding that Roche Bros. in fact acted unreasonably on the facts, so the case is authority for the legal principle, not for a factual finding of breach in this instance.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Adopting this new approach to premises liability does not make the owner of a self-service or modem grocery store an insurer against all accidents... but would only make an owner liable if the owner could reasonably foresee that a dangerous condition exists and failed to take adequate steps to forestall resulting injuries. A plaintiff would still be required to present evidence... and to bear the burden of persuading the trier of fact that the defendant acted unreasonably in the circumstances.

Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.raw_text: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342 (1983)
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.proposition: Plaintiff exercised reasonable care for her own safety at all times.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not state or hold that the plaintiff (or decedent) exercised reasonable care for his own safety at all times. Instead, it assumes for certification purposes only the parties’ allegations, including Firestone’s allegations of contributory negligence by Mr. Correia, and then addresses how such negligence interacts with comparative negligence and warranty doctrines. The court’s analysis is about the legal effect of potential negligence by the decedent and employer, not about finding that the decedent acted reasonably.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.relevant_excerpt: “Firestone denies any negligence or breach of warranty and alleges contributory negligence by Mr. Correia, particularly with respect to his failure to control the rig after the blowout, his failure to properly inspect and maintain the rig and its tires, and his failure to wear a seatbelt.”

Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694 (.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained personal injuries, physical pain and suffering, medical expenses, and lost income.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694 (.support_reasoning: The case discusses negligence elements generally, including causation and actual loss, but the holding is that the plaintiffs failed to establish causation and thus could not recover for their injuries and related damages. The opinion does not affirm that, in this case, the defendant’s negligence directly and proximately caused the plaintiffs’ personal injuries, pain and suffering, medical expenses, or lost income; it concludes the opposite. Therefore, it does not support the specific causation-and-damages proposition asserted.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694 (.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs…failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them….”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s breach of duty.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that harm to a law enforcement officer shot by Jason was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Kask’s failure to ensure proper storage of firearms and her granting him unsupervised access. The opinion repeatedly ties duty to the foreseeability of the risk that Jason would steal a gun and commit a violent crime, making clear that the plaintiff’s injuries were a foreseeable consequence of the alleged breach of duty.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: Defendant is liable for the negligent acts of its employees under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that traditional respondeat superior applies to a physician’s employer and that the employer may be vicariously liable for the negligent acts of its physician-employee committed within the scope of employment. The court expressly rejects any special requirement that the employer control the details of medical decision-making, confirming that an employer is liable for employee torts under ordinary respondeat superior principles.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “Because we conclude that traditional respondeat superior liability applies to the employer of a physician, and that to establish such liability it is not necessary that the employer have the right or ability to control the specific treatment decisions of a physician-employee, we vacate the judgment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment… occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. … ‘[a]n employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.’”}

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: The Massachusetts comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, governs apportionment of fault, but Plaintiff denies any comparative fault herein.

FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.raw_text: FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass. 393 (1993)
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff suffered damages as recognized under Massachusetts law, including physical pain and suffering, lost wages, and medical expenses.
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.case_name: FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co.
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses only economic loss resulting from power outages and holds that purely economic losses are not recoverable in negligence or contract absent personal injury or property damage. It does not discuss, identify, or recognize specific categories of damages such as physical pain and suffering, lost wages, or medical expenses. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that the plaintiff suffered such recognized damages under Massachusetts law.
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "We have recently affirmed that purely economic losses are unrecoverable in tort and strict liability actions in the absence of personal injury or property damage. ... Even if, as the plaintiffs contend, Edison committed gross negligence, there is nothing in the tariff that creates a right to recover for economic loss absent physical damage."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B\u20136C.proposition: Award interest and costs as permitted under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6C;
